words.definition: characterized by irony; happening in the opposite way to what is expected
words.sentence: It was ironic that the fire station burned down.

words.definition: having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations or people
words.sentence: His astute investment in the startup proved profitable.

words.definition: a person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage
words.sentence: The CEO was surrounded by sycophants who never criticized his decisions.

words.definition: praise enthusiastically
words.sentence: The mayor extolled the community's efforts in city beautification.

words.definition: a person who believes in or tries to bring about anarchy
words.sentence: The anarchist advocated for a society without government.

words.definition: relating to or situated on the edge or periphery of something
words.sentence: The new mall was built in a peripheral area of the city.

words.definition: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, typically someone who has just died
words.sentence: At the memorial, his brother gave a heartfelt eulogy.

words.definition: the act or process of doing what you have been asked or ordered to do
words.sentence: The company was fined for non-compliance with safety regulations.

words.definition: excessive, irrational zeal
words.sentence: His fanaticism for the cause made him overlook practical considerations.

words.definition: the feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect
words.sentence: She looked at the cheap imitation with disdain.

words.definition: a person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes
words.sentence: The philanthropist donated a significant sum to rebuild the local school.

words.definition: a thing that discourages or is intended to discourage someone from doing something
words.sentence: The high fines were meant to act as a deterrent to littering.

words.definition: a mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing
words.sentence: He used the euphemism 'passed away' instead of saying 'died'.

words.definition: to absolve someone from blame for a fault or wrongdoing
words.sentence: New evidence came to light that exonerated the accused.

words.definition: formal disapproval, especially when voted by a public body
words.sentence: The senator faced censure from his colleagues for his unethical behavior.

words.definition: inclined to lay down principles as undeniably true
words.sentence: He was so dogmatic about his theories that he dismissed all opposing views.

words.definition: one's opponent in a contest, conflict, or dispute
words.sentence: In the courtroom, the defense attorney faced a formidable adversary.

words.definition: including all elements or aspects; fully comprehensive
words.sentence: The team conducted an exhaustive search for the missing documents.

words.definition: swell or cause to swell by pressure from within
words.sentence: His stomach distended after eating the large meal.

words.definition: a threatened penalty for disobeying a law or rule
words.sentence: The international community imposed sanctions to enforce compliance.

words.definition: using very few words
words.sentence: His laconic reply was simply, 'Done.'

words.definition: lacking sense or meaning; silly
words.sentence: The inane chatter of the reality show bored him.

words.definition: open to more than one interpretation; not having one obvious meaning
words.sentence: The ambiguous ending of the movie left everyone debating.

words.definition: alternate or waver between different opinions or courses of action
words.sentence: She vacillated for weeks before deciding on a major.

words.definition: formally declare one's abandonment of (a claim, right, or possession)
words.sentence: He renounced his citizenship to live abroad.

words.definition: convenient and practical although possibly improper or immoral
words.sentence: It was expedient to overlook his minor faults for the greater good.

words.definition: not able to be forgotten or removed
words.sentence: The experience made an indelible impression on her memory.

words.definition: match or surpass (a person or achievement), typically by imitation
words.sentence: Young athletes often try to emulate their sports heroes.

words.definition: difficult to find, catch, or achieve
words.sentence: The solution to the puzzle remained elusive.

words.definition: a person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy
words.sentence: She was a strong advocate for environmental conservation.

words.definition: prevent from happening; make impossible
words.sentence: His schedule precluded any chance of attending the event.

words.definition: concise and exact use of words in writing or speech
words.sentence: Brevity in his instructions was appreciated during the crisis.

words.definition: humor or frivolousness, especially in the treatment of a serious matter
words.sentence: His levity at the funeral was considered inappropriate.

words.definition: inborn; natural
words.sentence: Her innate ability to connect with people made her an excellent diplomat.

words.definition: of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true
words.sentence: The story about the founder's early life turned out to be apocryphal.

words.definition: not able to be denied or disputed
words.sentence: The evidence against him was incontrovertible.

words.definition: a tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true
words.sentence: His credulity made him fall for the scam.

words.definition: confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding)
words.sentence: Witnesses corroborated the victim's account of the event.

words.definition: fond of company; sociable
words.sentence: She was gregarious and enjoyed meeting new people at parties.

words.definition: (of a body of water or the atmosphere of a confined space) having no current or flow and often having an unpleasant smell as a consequence
words.sentence: The stagnant pond was covered in green algae.

words.definition: happening as a minor accompaniment to something else
words.sentence: The incidental expenses of the trip included snacks and souvenirs.

words.definition: spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people
words.sentence: The pervasive influence of technology is undeniable.

words.definition: the establishment or starting point of an institution or activity
words.sentence: From its inception, the charity aimed to help homeless youth.

words.definition: a person who lives a solitary life and tends to avoid other people
words.sentence: After the scandal, he chose to live as a recluse.

words.definition: not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something
words.sentence: The modern sculpture looked incongruous among the classical statues.

words.definition: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation
words.sentence: She was in a quandary over whether to accept the job offer.

words.definition: having a red or flushed complexion
words.sentence: His face became florid after running up the stairs.

words.definition: having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure
words.sentence: He left a cryptic note on the table before he disappeared.

words.definition: reject (someone or something) in an abrupt or ungracious manner
words.sentence: She rebuffed his advances with a sharp comment.

words.definition: producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring
words.sentence: The prolific writer published over 50 novels in his lifetime.

words.definition: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
words.sentence: Her meticulous planning ensured the event went off without a hitch.

words.definition: the practice of persuading someone to do something by using force or threats
words.sentence: The confession was later dismissed due to claims of coercion.

words.definition: describe or portray (something) precisely
words.sentence: The map clearly delineates the boundaries of the national park.

words.definition: remove from office suddenly and forcefully
words.sentence: The military staged a coup to depose the corrupt leader.

words.definition: bitterly hostile
words.sentence: The debate turned virulent when personal insults were thrown.

words.definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
words.sentence: Despite the evidence, he remained obdurate in his beliefs.

words.definition: of or characteristic of a miser, especially in being stingy with money
words.sentence: His miserly habits meant he never spent on anything unnecessary.

words.definition: distribute or spread over a wide area
words.sentence: After the rally, the crowd began to disperse in different directions.

words.definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
words.sentence: He longed for adventure, tired of the mundane routine.

words.definition: make (something bad) less severe, serious, or painful
words.sentence: Efforts were made to mitigate the effects of the oil spill on wildlife.

words.definition: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, typically someone who has just died
words.sentence: At the memorial, his brother gave a heartfelt eulogy.

words.definition: the act or process of doing what you have been asked or ordered to do
words.sentence: The company was fined for non-compliance with safety regulations.

words.definition: excessive, irrational zeal
words.sentence: His fanaticism for the cause made him overlook practical considerations.

words.definition: the feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect
words.sentence: She looked at the cheap imitation with disdain.

words.definition: a person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes
words.sentence: The philanthropist donated a significant sum to rebuild the local school.

words.definition: a thing that discourages or is intended to discourage someone from doing something
words.sentence: The high fines were meant to act as a deterrent to littering.

words.definition: Some teachers consider student apathy to be the number one problem with schools.
words.sentence: Student apathy towards education has become a significant concern for educators.

words.definition: A firm believer in old-fashioned courtesy, Miss Post deprecated the modern tendency to address new acquaintances by their first names.
words.sentence: Miss Post deprecated the casualness of addressing elders by their first names, favoring traditional etiquette.

words.definition: a digital currency in which transactions are verified and records maintained by a decentralized system using cryptography, rather than by a centralized authority
words.sentence: Bitcoin is the most well-known cryptocurrency.

words.definition: a chemical substance which is released at the end of a nerve fiber by the arrival of a nerve impulse and, by diffusing across the synapse or junction, effects the transfer of the impulse to another nerve fiber
words.sentence: Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that plays several important roles in the brain and body.

words.definition: the value of the shares issued by a company
words.sentence: Investors are interested in the equity value of the startup for potential returns.

words.definition: a bacterium, virus, or other microorganism that can cause disease
words.sentence: Sanitizing surfaces can help reduce the spread of pathogens.

words.definition: a process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer
words.sentence: The algorithm used by the search engine sorts results based on relevance.

words.definition: a type of cell division that results in two daughter cells each having the same number and kind of chromosomes as the parent nucleus
words.sentence: During mitosis, the nucleus of the cell divides into two nuclei containing the same number of chromosomes.

words.definition: Don't just hint around that you're dissatisfied. Be explicit about what's bothering you.
words.sentence: During the meeting, he was explicit about his dissatisfaction with the project's progress.

words.definition: Diane tried to cajole her father into letting her have the car tonight.
words.sentence: Diane attempted to cajole her father into lending her the car for the evening with promises of good behavior.

words.definition: of or relating to government revenue, especially taxes
words.sentence: The government is reviewing its fiscal policy to increase revenue.

words.definition: capable of being broken down by the action of living organisms
words.sentence: Biodegradable plastics are being developed to reduce environmental impact.

words.definition: a typical example or pattern of something; a model
words.sentence: The shift to renewable energy sources represents a new paradigm in energy production.

words.definition: the branch of science that deals with the study of viruses
words.sentence: Virology has been at the forefront of research during pandemics.

words.definition: a sum of money paid regularly by a company to its shareholders out of its profits (or reserves)
words.sentence: The company declared a quarterly dividend of $0.50 per share.

words.definition: avoidance of the depletion of natural resources in order to maintain an ecological balance
words.sentence: Sustainability is key in modern urban planning.

words.definition: relating to the circulatory system, which comprises the heart and blood vessels
words.sentence: Cardiovascular health is crucial for longevity.

words.definition: a system in which records of transactions are maintained across several computers that are linked in a peer-to-peer network
words.sentence: Blockchain technology provides a high level of security for transactions.

words.definition: a proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation
words.sentence: Her hypothesis was that sugar intake directly influences hyperactivity in children.

words.definition: the availability of liquid assets to a market or company
words.sentence: The company's liquidity was questioned by investors after a series of poor financial decisions.

words.definition: the ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections, especially in response to learning or experience or following injury
words.sentence: Neuroplasticity explains why stroke survivors can often regain functions.

words.definition: a government authority or license conferring a right or title for a set period, especially the sole right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention
words.sentence: The inventor filed for a patent to protect his innovative design.

words.definition: the branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings
words.sentence: Ecology studies how ecosystems work and the relationships within them.

words.definition: a general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money
words.sentence: Inflation is often measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

words.definition: based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic
words.sentence: The study used empirical data to support its findings.

words.definition: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected
words.sentence: The unexpected results were initially considered an anomaly.

words.definition: an examination of tissue removed from a living body to discover the presence, cause, or extent of a disease
words.sentence: A biopsy confirmed the presence of malignant cells.

words.definition: the income returned on an investment, such as the interest or dividends received from holding a particular security
words.sentence: The bond's yield has increased due to the rise in interest rates.

words.definition: interaction between two different organisms living in close physical association, typically to the advantage of both
words.sentence: The relationship between the clownfish and sea anemones is a classic example of symbiosis.

words.definition: a step-by-step procedure for calculations, data processing, and automated reasoning
words.sentence: Sorting algorithms help arrange data in a specific order efficiently.

words.definition: a measure of the disorder or randomness in a closed system
words.sentence: The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system cannot decrease over time.

words.definition: making an investment to reduce the risk of adverse price movements in an asset
words.sentence: Farmers often use futures markets for hedging against price drops in crops.

words.definition: the study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics
words.sentence: Genetics has revolutionized our understanding of diseases at the molecular level.

words.definition: of or relating to a loan or credit of a type granted to borrowers perceived as having a higher-than-average risk of default
words.sentence: The financial crisis was partly due to the collapse of the subprime mortgage market.

words.definition: the process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water
words.sentence: Photosynthesis is crucial for the survival of plants and the production of oxygen.

words.definition: relating to or having the function of regulation
words.sentence: The new regulatory measures aim to ensure fair competition in the market.

words.definition: wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
words.sentence: Couch potatoes lead an indolent life.

words.definition: extreme or alarming importance; seriousness
words.sentence: We could tell we were in serious trouble from the gravity of the principal's expression.

words.definition: the branch of medicine that deals with the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer
words.sentence: He specializes in pediatric oncology, focusing on childhood cancers.

words.definition: a fundamental change in underlying assumptions or concepts
words.sentence: The discovery of quantum mechanics represented a paradigm shift in physics.

words.definition: the branch of medicine which deals with the incidence, distribution, and possible control of diseases and other factors relating to health
words.sentence: Epidemiology was crucial in tracking and controlling the spread of the virus.

words.definition: currency that a government has declared to be legal tender, but it is not backed by a physical commodity
words.sentence: The value of fiat money is derived from the economic activity and trust in the issuing government rather than any physical asset.

words.definition: the branch of mechanics that deals with the mathematical description of the motion and interaction of subatomic particles
words.sentence: Quantum mechanics has led to advancements in computing, communication, and imaging technologies.

words.definition: based on random choice or personal whim
words.sentence: Tom's arbitrary dismissal angered him; his boss had no reason to fire him.

words.definition: a group of technologies that give scientists the ability to change an organism's DNA
words.sentence: CRISPR is one of the tools used in genome editing to correct genetic defects.

words.definition: the ability of a company to meet its long-term fixed expenses and to accomplish long-term expansion and growth
words.sentence: The solvency of the firm was in question when it could not repay its long-term debts.

words.definition: the branch of biomedical science that deals with the immune system, its components, functions, and disorders
words.sentence: His research in immunology focuses on vaccine development.

words.definition: the process by which the information in a strand of DNA is copied into a new molecule of messenger RNA
words.sentence: Transcription is one of the steps in gene expression.

words.definition: Lack of parental affirmation can harm a child's emotional development.
words.sentence: The lack of affirmation from her parents left her feeling unvalued throughout her childhood.

words.definition: Rumors of police corruption led the mayor to instigate an investigation into the department.
words.sentence: The mayor decided to instigate a thorough investigation after hearing about widespread corruption allegations.

words.definition: a discrete quantity of energy proportional in magnitude to the frequency of the radiation it represents
words.sentence: Quantum computers operate using qubits, which can be in multiple states simultaneously.

words.definition: a large naturally occurring community of flora and fauna occupying a major habitat
words.sentence: The Amazon rainforest is one of the Earth's most significant biomes.

words.definition: At the protest, the students cheered the strikers with fervor.
words.sentence: The crowd at the rally expressed their support for the workers with great fervor.

words.definition: The hack writer's worn-out cliches made his book seem banal.
words.sentence: His attempt at poetry was dismissed as banal due to the overuse of tired metaphors.

words.definition: Their disparity in rank made no difference to the prince and Cinderella.
words.sentence: Despite their social disparity, the prince and Cinderella found common ground in their kindness.

words.definition: There is a fine line between speech that is terse and to the point, and speech that is too abrupt.
words.sentence: His response was terse, yet it conveyed everything he needed to say without any fluff.

words.definition: Betsy lacked the heart to tell June that the wedding present was superfluous; they had already received five toasters.
words.sentence: Betsy couldn't bring herself to mention that June's gift of another toaster was superfluous.

words.definition: This article lampoons the pretensions of some movie actors.
words.sentence: The editorial humorously lampooned the exaggerated lifestyle of Hollywood celebrities.

words.definition: All the people commented how glorious the emperor looked in his resplendent new clothes.
words.sentence: The emperor appeared resplendent at the parade, his attire shimmering in the sunlight.

words.definition: Shocked by the viciousness of the bombing, politicians condemned the terrorists' reprehensible deed.
words.sentence: Politicians across the spectrum condemned the act as reprehensible, calling for justice.

words.definition: Couch potatoes lead an indolent life.
words.sentence: His indolent lifestyle was evident from his reluctance to do any form of physical activity.

words.definition: We could tell we were in serious trouble from the gravity of the principal's expression.
words.sentence: The gravity of the situation was clear when the principal's face turned stern.

words.definition: the branch of physics concerned with the nature of motion, especially of matter moved by forces
words.sentence: The study of chemical kinetics involves the speed of chemical reactions.

words.definition: the use of borrowed funds for investment, expecting the profits made to be greater than the interest payable
words.sentence: The company decided to take on more leverage to finance its expansion.

words.definition: Jim's severe bout of the flu debilitated him so much he couldn't go to school.
words.sentence: The flu had debilitated Jim so severely that he missed a week of school.

words.definition: Tom's arbitrary dismissal angered him; his boss had no reason to fire him.
words.sentence: Tom was outraged by his arbitrary dismissal from work, as there was no apparent reason for his firing.

words.definition: Lack of parental affirmation can harm a child's emotional development.
words.sentence: Lack of parental affirmation can harm a child's emotional development.

words.definition: to bring about or initiate (an action or event)
words.sentence: Rumors of police corruption led the mayor to instigate an investigation into the department.

words.definition: stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt
words.sentence: Don't just hint around that you're dissatisfied. Be explicit about what's bothering you.

words.definition: persuade (someone) to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery
words.sentence: Diane tried to cajole her father into letting her have the car tonight.

words.definition: intense and passionate feeling
words.sentence: At the protest, the students cheered the strikers with fervor.

words.definition: so lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring
words.sentence: The hack writer's worn-out clich's made his book seem banal.

words.definition: fluent or persuasive speaking or writing
words.sentence: Her eloquence in debates made her a popular speaker at the university.

words.definition: assign an inferior rank or position to
words.sentence: After the financial scandal, the CEO was relegated to a lesser role within the company.

words.definition: remove the moisture from (something); dry thoroughly
words.sentence: He used a desiccant to desiccate the samples for long-term preservation.

words.definition: slow and clumsy because of great weight
words.sentence: The ponderous machinery moved with a loud clanking noise.

words.definition: lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern
words.sentence: The general apathy towards the election was a cause for concern.

words.definition: having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual
words.sentence: The precocious child was already reading Shakespeare at age seven.

words.definition: the quality of being religious or reverent
words.sentence: The nuns were noted for their piety.

words.definition: existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence
words.sentence: To him, hunger was an abstract concept; he never missed a meal.

words.definition: to treat (something sacred) with abuse, irreverence, or contempt
words.sentence: Tourists are urged not to profane the sanctity of holy places by wearing improper garb.

words.definition: widespread in a particular area or at a particular time
words.sentence: Reed had no patience with the views prevalent in America of his day.

words.definition: a feeling of fear or agitation about something that might happen
words.sentence: As she entered the office of the dean, Sharon felt some trepidation about how much trouble she was in.

words.definition: the appearance or quality of being arrogantly superior and disdainful
words.sentence: I resent his haughtiness because he is no better than we are.

words.definition: introducing new ideas
words.sentence: Her innovative design won first prize.

words.definition: feeling great happiness
words.sentence: The jubilant team celebrated their victory.

words.definition: family relationship or connection
words.sentence: They felt a strong kinship after working together.

words.definition: bright or shining
words.sentence: The luminous moon lit up the night sky.

words.definition: courage in facing difficulty
words.sentence: He showed great fortitude during his recovery.

words.definition: having high moral qualities
words.sentence: Her noble actions inspired others.

words.definition: kind and generous
words.sentence: The benevolent donor gave to many charities.

words.definition: showing care and effort in work
words.sentence: Her diligent studying paid off with high grades.

words.definition: fluent and persuasive in speaking
words.sentence: The eloquent speech moved the entire audience.

words.definition: courage in facing difficulty
words.sentence: He showed great fortitude during his recovery.

words.definition: feeling of thankfulness
words.sentence: She expressed gratitude for their help.

words.definition: modest and unpretentious
words.sentence: Despite his success, he remained humble.

words.definition: something suggested or indirectly expressed
words.sentence: When Miss Watson said she hadn't seen her purse since the last time Jim was in the house, the implication was that she suspected Jim.

words.definition: make legally void or invalid
words.sentence: Once the contract was nullified, it no longer had any legal force.

words.definition: gloomily or sullenly ill-humored
words.sentence: Forced to take early retirement, Jill acted morose for months.

words.definition: exceeding what is necessary or normal
words.sentence: Saying 'we collaborated together' is a redundant phrase. If you collaborated then you obviously worked together.

words.definition: using wit or sarcasm to criticize
words.sentence: The humor of cartoonist Gary Trudeau is often satirical.

words.definition: violent or unsteady movement
words.sentence: The year 2024 will be a year filled with turbulence.

words.definition: the state of being famous for something bad
words.sentence: If the singer couldn't have a good reputation, he would settle for notoriety.

words.definition: displaying wealth or importance in a showy way
words.sentence: The casino in Atlantic City is the most ostentatious gambling palace in the world.

words.definition: done without care or interest, purely for form
words.sentence: The auditor's perfunctory inspection of the books overlooked many errors.

words.definition: pretending to have qualities or beliefs that you do not have
words.sentence: Believing Eddie to be interested only in his own advancement, Greg resented his hypocritical posing as a friend.

words.definition: lacking originality; overused
words.sentence: When the reviewer criticized the movie for its hackneyed plot, all agreed we had seen similar movies.

words.definition: person devoted to pleasure
words.sentence: As a hedonist, she refused to do anything that required hard work.

words.definition: based on assumptions rather than facts
words.sentence: Why do we have to consider hypothetical cases when we have actual case histories to examine?

words.definition: opinion contrary to accepted belief
words.sentence: He was threatened with excommunication because his remarks were considered heresy.

words.definition: lacking seriousness; not having any serious purpose
words.sentence: Though Nancy enjoyed Bill's frivolous companionship, she sometimes wondered if he could be serious.

words.definition: based on a mistaken belief
words.sentence: Your reasoning must be fallacious because it leads to a ridiculous answer.

words.definition: to make someone feel intimidated or apprehensive
words.sentence: Boast all you like, but you cannot daunt me.

words.definition: having or showing excessive willingness to serve or please
words.sentence: Constantly fawning on his employer, Uriah Heep was a servile individual.
